thread.title_full: ‘I spent a week in the NHL: It was all drinking, fighting, sex’ | New York Post

author: Anthony Barstow
title: ‘I spent a week in the NHL: It was all drinking, fighting, sex’
text:
If you never had the chance to join a fraternity, maybe try the next best thing: trying out for an NHL team.
As amateur Irish hurler Lee Chin found out, it’s mostly drinking and fighting.
Chin joined the Vancouver Canucks for a week as part of the Irish reality show “Toughest Trades,” in which players from different sports swap professions, and he said he “couldn’t believe” all the drinking he saw and the laissez-faire attitude about fighting.
“The drinking culture they have, I couldn’t believe it,” Chin said in an interview with the Irish Times . “They were lowering pints the day before the game, and that was sitting at lunch. … And managers and coaches and everyone sitting around, and I was thinking, ‘I wouldn’t do this in front of [Wexford hurling manager Davy Fitzgerald].’ I wouldn’t do it if I was at home on my own, never mind in front of Davy, but they just believe in it.”
Not only was drinking in front the coaches acceptable, Chin said, but it was sometimes a strategy to break out of a slump.
“They have this thing called a ‘change-up,’ when a player is not on form, not scoring,” Chin said. “The manager will call a change-up, and basically, that player has to go out and ruin himself for the night then come back the next day with the attitude of you just don’t care.”
How exactly would a player “ruin himself” for the night, you ask?
“They send him out, drink 20 pints, go off with a couple of women, whatever he wants, and come back the next day,” Chin said. “That’s the way they live. It’s the culture, what they believe in, letting off steam like that. I don’t know if they look at the science behind it.”
As far as the fighting, Chin said he initially thought it was “barbaric,” but he came to understand it in his time with the Canucks.
“I picked a lot of brains, asked a lot of lads what was the fighting about,” he said. “What fascinated me was the player power, the whole running that allows players to throw off the gloves and fight. I thought at first this was so barbaric, allowed to go on in sport, it’s crazy like.
“The players were able to explain, and I was so intrigued by it and the reasoning behinds it. Literally, it’s the players that police that ruling, and there’s nothing in the rule book to say you can’t do it. It’s there for the players to protect them. If a guy is acting the maggot with another player on the ice, he has to pay for it, and that’s the way it’s done.”
Chin swapped places with former Canucks goalie Alex Auld, who spent a week with Chin’s hurling club in Wexford, Ireland. For Chin’s sake, let’s hope the drinking-and-fighting ethos of the NHL didn’t rub off on the Wexford squad.
